div.p: Mr. Colman's SERMONS ON THE Holy Sabbath.

The Doctrine and Law OF THE Holy Sabbath: In the Order wherein it lies through the Scriptures of the Old and New Teſtament. IN TWO SERMONS, Preached at the Lecture in Boſton, October 15. and December 10. 1724.
By Benjamin Colman.
div.q:
Sint oculi, manuſ
que veſtrae toto illo die ad Deum expanſae.
div.p: BOSTON: Printed by T. Fleet, for Thomas Hancock, and Sold at his Shop in Ann-Street, near the Draw-Bridge. 1725.

div.head: TO THE READER
div.p:
IT is only the Scriptural way of treating this Noble Subject, that hath inclined me to make public the following Diſcourſes. It ſeems to me the Method moſt eaſie and perſpicuous, moſt natural and juſt, moſt profitable and acceptable to them that value the Subject; which all ſerious Chriſtians will do. You have here almoſt the whole voice of Scripture concerning the Holy Sabbath of the Lord in a very ſmall compaſs, and the ſeveral Texts almoſt in the ſame Order wherein they lie in the Holy Bible. I would hope by this means, as thro' a Burning glaſs (under the Bleſſing of the ſanctifying Spirit) to collect the rayes of the Divine light, and bear them down with heavenly heat upon the Reader's mind and heart.— Not that by any Art of mine the Glaſs of the Word can be thus form'd
and faſhion'd; but I have found it thus form'd and faſhion'd to my hand by the Bleſſed Inſpirer of it, and bring it a ſacred Mite to the Treaſurie of the Sanctuary from whence I received it. May the Lord of the Sabbath pleaſe to accept the Offering, and effectually own it by bleſſing it to its deſired End; which is to enlighten us more in, and animate us more unto, this great and ſingular Duty of Man thro' out all Generations, the keeping holy the Sabbath Day.— I have not gone formally into Directions and Motives on this Head, which are abundant in many Treatiſes already in your hands; but I hope the Reader will find theſe every where ſuggeſted to him thro' the Diſcourſes before him; and in a particular manner be led and excited to conſider and improve his Sabbaths as a Sign and Memorial of the Covenant of Grace, and the bleſſed Seaſons and Means of Sanctification.— So our Fathers, like wiſe and good Men, began with God in the planting of theſe Churches: They covenanted with God to be his People and to keep his Sabbaths, and they found Him to be the Lord their Sanctifier. The reverend Obſervation of the Lords-day was their diſtinguiſhing honour and glory, and the fruits of holineſs to the praiſe and glory of God abounded
among them.— As the World grows upon us in its numbers and trade, we are growing out of this our primitive purity and beauty; but it is viſible that the decay of Sanctity bears proportion to our declenſion in Sabbath Sanctification. We had need therefore to remember how we have received and heard, and hold faſt and repent; let no man take our Crown. I know no one Rule more compendious, comprehenſive and effectual for the revival and perpetuity of Religion among us than this, that we keep the LORD's Sabbaths, as a Sign between Him and us thro' out our Generations, that HE is the Lord that doth ſanctify us.

q.p: And the Lord ſpake unto Moſes, ſaying, Speak thou alſo unto the Children of Iſrael, ſaying,
Verily my Sabbaths ye ſhall keep; for it is a ſign between me and you thro' out your Generations; that ye may know that I am the Lord that doth ſanctify you.

div.p: IN theſe words the great Law of the Sabbath is repeated to Moſes, and by him unto the Children of Iſrael, with an awful preface and a moſt powerful reaſon annexed. The preface is much the ſame with that from Heaven, and Sinai, before the ten Commandments; And God ſpake all theſe Words ſaying, I am the Lord thy God. Let us reverently attend and anſwer, I will hear what God the Lord will ſpeak.

THE Commandment is here given in the moſt auguſt, authoritative and peremptory manner:
Verily my Sabbaths ye ſhall keep. More Authority and Commandment can't well be put into fewer words.

Laſtly, HERE is a ſpecial and moſt weighty reaſon annexed, to inforce the precept: for it is a ſign, &c. It is great condeſcention and grace in God to us, to annex a reaſon to any of his Commands. His ſovereign Will is the higheſt reaſon. But there is much of Majeſty and much Grace in this reaſon: It is a ſign between me and you: And will God in very deed give us ſuch a ſign and token between Himſelf and us? will he in very deed deal ſo with man upon earth? And give a ſtanding ſign too thro' out all the Generations of man on earth? O the favour and grace to duſt, while he humbles himſelf to behold the things that are above!

BUT what is the Lord's Sabbath a ſign of thro' all our Generations? Why it ſignifies and lets us know 1. that he is the Lord: Lord of the world, Lord of our time, Lord of our lives; the great Proprietor and abſolute Diſpoſer of them. And 2. that he is the Lord our Sanctifier: that I am the Lord that doth ſanctify you.

BUT how the Sabbath is a ſign of this, and why this is a reaſon for our keeping and ſanctifying the Sabbath, is to be ſaid under the Doctrines, which are theſe two:
1. That the Great GOD vehemently requires of us the Sanctification of his Sabbath.
2. That it is a ſign between Him and us that He is the Lord our Sanctifier.

1. D. THE Lord our God has moſt ſtrictly and vehemently required the Obſervation and keeping
Sabbath. Verily my Sabbaths ye ſhall keep. Words can't be ſtricter than theſe are. And in this manner the precept is always given: Ye ſhall keep my Sabbaths, I am the Lord. Lev. 19.30 — I ſhall only obſerve to you how ſtrictly and vehemently this law of the Sabbath is inſiſted on thro' the whole Bible.

I. IT was a Law to man from the beginning of the world, and the firſt Law (and ſecond Bleſſing) that was given to man, even in Paradiſe, in his ſtate of innocence. For if man had never ſinned, yet there would for ever have remained to him the keeping of a Sabbath, every ſeventh day: As you read, Gen. 2.1, 2, 3. Thus the heavens and the earth were finiſhed and all the hoſt of them, ond on the ſeventh day God ended his Work which he had made, and he reſted on the ſeventh day from all his work which he had made; and God bleſſed the ſeventh day and ſanctified it, becauſe that in it he had reſted from all his work which he had created and made. So from the Creation of the world God inſtituted a weekly Sabbath, for the perpetual ſolemn praiſes of the Creator from the Sons of men. He ſanctified the Day, to be the ſpecial Time of their bleſſing Him and his bleſſing them. Bp. Patrick. The ſeventh day was ordained a Univerſal and Everlaſting holy Feſtival from the Day wherein Man was created. This magnifies the Sabbath and makes it honourable, and ſacred for ever to us, that it was the firſt of God's Laws to man. Thus we keep the Earths birth-day Dr. Edwards. : It is a ſacred
Feſtival in memory of the Worlds nativity. And it leaves us no room to queſtion Adam's keeping the Sabbath day.

THIS ſolemn and early Injunction of a Sabbath to man is a Circumſtance that puts great honour and dignity upon the Sabbath-day. It was ordained for the ſpecial honour and perpetual worſhip of the Lord our Maker, immediatly upon the Creation of our firſt Parents, and in their paradiſaic ſtate.

WE read of Noah, Gen. 8.10, 12. that he ſtaid yet other ſeven days, and again he ſent forth the Dove out of the Ark. It appears by this, ſays Bp. Patrick, that on the ſeventh day Noah expected a Bleſſing rather than on another day; it being the day devoted from the Beginning to religious ſervices.

II. THE ſanctification of the Sabbath was one of the firſt things given in Commandment to Iſrael upon their leaving Egypt. God was now gathering and forming to himſelf a Church in the earth, and it was fitting and neceſſary to remember them of his Sabbath upon their ſetting out toward Canaan, the Type of the everlaſting Sabbatiſm. They had it may be almoſt loſt the Remembrance of his Sabbaths in Egypt, at leaſt many of them; but Moſes is directed by God to mind them of it, and that not as a novel but an ancient thing. See Exod. 16. It was upon the firſt proviſion of Manna for the Camp of Iſrael: In the 4 and 5 verſes of that Chapter, the Lord ſaid to Moſes, Behold I will rain bread from heaven for you, and the people ſhall gather a certain rate every day; but on the ſixth day they ſhall prepare twice
as much as on the other days: Accordingly, as we read on from the 22 verſe of that Chapter, on the ſixth day the people gathered twice as much bread, two Omers for one man; and the Rulers came and told Moſes: Then he ſaid unto them, This is that which the Lord hath ſaid, To morrow is the Reſt of the Holy Sabbath to the Lord; then ye ſhall not find it in the field; ſix days ye ſhall gather it, but on the ſeventh day (which is the Sabbath) in it there ſhall be none: See, for the Lord hath given you the Sabbath; therefore he giveth you on the ſixth day the bread of two days: Abide every man in his place, let no man go out on the Sabbath day. So the people reſted on the ſeventh day.

YOU will eaſily obſerve from the whole of this paſſage, that it ſuppoſes the people of Iſrael acquainted with the Law of the Sabbath. It was not now Inſtituted, but the Inſtitution was improved and acted on; firſt by God in his Providence for the magnifying the Day to Iſrael, a double portion of Manna falling (it is likely) on the ſixth day; and then by the People, they gathering thereon the portion of two days.

THIS was before the peoples arrival at Sinai, even upon their entring into the Wilderneſs; and it remained to them thro' it a laſting Sign and Miracle from heaven in honour of the Sabbath day. For if on any other day of the week they left of their manna till the morning it bred worms and ſtank, but it kept good and ſweet when they laid it up for the Sabbath day.

"THUS the Law of the Sabbath was given to Iſrael before the delivery of the Law from Sinai, and the Day was kept before the Decalogue
was given: the Inſtitution was before the Law of Moſes.
Dr. Edwards.

III. THE Law of the Sabbath was one of the ten Words, the ten Commandments, given from Sinai, in that auguſt and fearful manner as you all know. On Sinai God repeated this his Law out of the midſt of the fire. God himſelf came down that day from Heaven with his mighty Angels; he came down in thick darkneſs and flames of devouring fire: Sinai was altogether in a ſmoke and the mountain quaked greatly; the Congregation below were ready to die with fear leſt the lightnings ſhould conſume them. Who of all fleſh, but they in that ſingular day, ever heard the voice of the living God ſpeaking out of the midſt of the fire and lived? In this manner did the great God give the fourth Commandment unto his Church, that they ſhould remember it and keep it for ever, and not dare to forget it. Deu. 4.9, 10. Only take heed to thy ſelf and keep thy ſoul diligently, leſt thou forget the things which thy eyes have ſeen, and leſt they depart from thy heart all the days of thy life; eſpecially the day that thou ſtoodeſt before the Lord thy God in Horeb, when the Lord ſaid unto me, Gather the people together, and I will make them hear my words, that they may learn to fear me all the days that they ſhall live upon the earth, and that they may teach their Children.—O that we and our Children may ever remember how, in what majeſty and terror, God has commanded us to keep holy the Sabbath day.

I need not add, how that after the great God had ſpoken this Law from heaven, he alſo wrote it on a Table of ſtone, with his own finger, to perpetuate the Remembrance and obſervation of it; and to imprint it upon the harder hearts and conſciences of men: And he only who wrote in the Table of ſtone, can write it on the fleſhly tables of our hearts. And that the whole might be yet more reverend and ſanctifying to us, he laid it up within the Holy of Holies, under the Mercy-ſeat.

Moreover, It pleaſed the Holy God to enlarge, in many weighty words, on this Law of the Sabbath, when he came down on Sinai. He charged them to remember this Law: he call'd it the Sabbath of the Lord their God: he told them when, and how, and why he ſanctified it. There is ſomething very awful in God's uſing all theſe obliging and conſtraining words. 'Twas a Law worthy to be thus ſolemnly revived and long inſiſted on: a very important point for the honour of God and our Salvation.—Wherefore let the Majeſty of that Day be evermore in the eyes and ears and hearts of the people of God.—To go on,

IV. THE Law of the Sabbath was repeated and inculcated upon the delivery of the Ceremonial and Judicial Law; yea it was inſerted into the latter, as being indeed a line and hedge about all the Statutes and Judgments of God given by the hand of Moſes; to keep them all from being broken. For indeed piety and religion, and alſo juſtice and righteouſneſs, flouriſh or decline
among the Covenant people of God, as the Sabbath is ſanctified or profaned among them. A ſpecial honour is put upon the fourth Commandment, and a ſpecial reverence to it is required from us, by God's repeating it to his Church on theſe great Occaſions. I will name them diſtinctly.

1. WE have in my Text and Context the Law of the Sabbath repeated upon the delivery of the Ceremonial Law. God having finiſh'd here his Orders and directions to Moſes concerning the Tabernacle of the Congregation, the Ark, the Mercy-ſeat, and all the furniture of the Tabernacle; the Table, the Candleſtic, and the Altar of Incenſe, the Altar of burnt-offering, the Laver and his foot; the Holy Garments, the anointing Oil and the ſweet Incenſe; Then the Lord added,— Speak thou unto the Children of Iſrael, Verily my Sabbaths you ſhall keep; it is a ſign between me and you thro' out your Generations, &c.

NOW the moſt learned Expoſitors upon my Text agree, that this Commandment is here repeated on this Occaſion, that ſo the people of God might not think that even the ſacred work of the Tabernacle might be done upon the Sabbath day. Even that Work of God, of whatever importance, neceſſity and haſte it were, would not warrant them to break the holy Reſt of God's Day. Mr. Clark therefore gives the Senſe of my text thus, Verily my Sabbaths you ſhall keep; i. e. notwithſtanding the work of the Tabernacle be holy, and diligently and ſpeedily to be done, yet I'll not have any of it done on the Sabbath day. And ſo Mr. Henry,
Even Tabernacle-work muſt give way to the Sabbath reſt: Sic volo iſta fieri, ut nihilominus opifices ceſſent Sabbatho opere. Pareus in loc.
They might not think this ſacred Work would warrant them to break the Sabbath. Bp. Patrick.
It means the work and labour of preparing and rearing the Tabernacle; not the Holy Services of it afterward; for ſo the Prieſts profaned the Sabbath and were guiltleſs; their Labours being in themſelves holy, like the work of Miniſters on the Lord's days under the Goſpel. So God himſelf has given the diſtinction between ſervile and holy work or labours. Lev. 23.25.

BUT the true and great Reaſon, as it ſeems to me, why God repeated the Law of his Sabbath unto Iſrael upon his giving the Ceremonial Law to them, was this— Becauſe the Ceremonial law was originally deſigned by God, and always ſubordinated and ſubſervient unto the Sanctification of the Sabbath, in the worſhip and ſervices of the Tabernacle and Temple. It was eminently inſtituted for this one end, the ſolemnizing of the Lord's Sabbaths at the Tabernacle. Then the offerings and ſacrifices were doubled, and therefore neceſſarily the Services of the Prieſts. Theſe were made for the Sabbath; and therefore no wonder that when theſe were inſtituted the Law of the Sabbath was repeated. But then,

2. THE Judicial Law which God gave to Iſrael by the hand of Moſes, had the Law of the Sabbath inſerted into it This forenſic or judicial Law was for the Civil Government of that People
of God, and contained a Body or Syſtem of Laws to be obſerved by the Magiſtrates and Rulers, for the good order and peaceable and quiet living of the people, in all Godlineſs and honeſty. Theſe Judgments Moſes began to ſet before them, by order from God, preſently after the delivery of the moral Law or ten Commandments. You have a great part of them in the 21, 22, and 23. Chapters of Exodus: And at the 12. verſe of the 23. Chapter you find an abſtract of the fourth Commandment, inſerted thus,—Six days ſhalt thou do thy work, and on the ſeventh day thou ſhalt reſt, that thine ox and thine aſs may reſt, and that the Son of thy handmaid and the ſtranger may be refreſhed. Here, as I take it, the fourth Commandment was made a Law of the State to Iſrael, whoſe Legiſlature was properly a Theocracy, and their Rulers and Magiſtrates had the Executive power and truſt committed to them. And doubtleſs God thus honour'd the Law of the Sabbath to Iſrael his people, by inſerting it in the Body of their Judicial Laws, to teach civil Governments to do the like in all parts and ages of the World, to whom the knowledge thereof ſhould come. And accordingly the good Government over us have in their wiſdom and piety Enacted the ſtrict Sanctification of the Lord's day, and have forbid the profanation of it under ſuch and ſuch penalties; wherein they have but done the part of a Chriſtian Government.

THUS the ſacred Law of ſanctifying the Sabbath ſtands in Scripture as a hedge about the whole Moſaic Law, both Ceremonial and Judicial.
For (as One ſays) where no Conſcience is made of keeping the Sabbath, farewel both Godlineſs and honeſty. God in his wiſdom and gracious care has therefore ſet the fourth Commandment (as it were) between the two Tables of the moral Law; and alſo drawn it (as it were) as a line about all his poſitive laws, ſtatutes and judgments; that none ſhould break over this and violate them.— But I go on,

V. GOD has from the beginning very dreadfully threatned, and terribly puniſhed the violation of the Sabbath. Laws are of little force without a Penalty, nor that without an Execution. The Threatnings of God, and his Judgments on ſinners, are as a flowing ſword to guard his Holy Sabbaths from profanation, and to keep men in the way to the tree of life. And here,
1. VERY dreadful are the Threatnings of God againſt thoſe that profane his Holy Sabbaths. In our Context the threatning is, v. 14. Every one that defileth the Sabbath ſhall ſurely be put to death; whoſoever doeth any work thereon, that ſoul ſhall be cut off from among his people. This was the penalty then incurred by Sabbath-breakers, and then inflicted by the Lord of the Sabbath. How ſevere a penalty! If any dar'd openly to profane the Sabbath in Iſrael, ſo that the Crime came to the notice of the Judge and were prov'd upon the offender, "the Magiſtrate "muſt cut him off by the ſword of Juſtice: But if the profanation were more hidden and cou'd not be prov'd upon him, or if the Magiſtrate were remiſs and did not do his duty,
then God wou'd take the work into his own hand, and cut him off by a ſtroke from heaven. This the Sabbath breaker might juſtly fear, and no doubt often ſuffer'd. But the ſpiritual Judgment of God and his Eternal puniſhment of this Sin, is infinitly greater. And if men deſpiſe God's Sabbaths, as it provokes him greatly to cut them off from among his people now, ſo without repentance he will cut them off for ever.
2. VERY dreadful have the puniſhments of this Sin been, by the immediate Commandment of God, to Rulers, or by the hand of his Providence.

BY the immediate and direct Command of the High God the firſt open and preſumptuous breaker of the Sabbath was puniſhed with death. You have the melancholly and diſmal Story, Num. 15. from the 3 • , to the 36. verſe. And while the Children of Iſrael were in the wilderneſs, they found a man that gathered ſticks on the Sabbath day: and they bro't him to Moſes and unto Aaron, and all the Congregation: And the Lord ſaid unto Moſes, the Man ſhall be ſurely put to death; all the Congregation ſhall ſtone him with ſtones without the Camp: And he died, as the Lord commanded Moſes. God made him an Example, to deter others for evermore from the like Sin.

BUT then alſo, God has in his Holy Providence dreadfully judg'd and puniſh'd for the Sin of Sabbath-breaking. How many he cuts off by untimely deaths for this ſin we know not; but there is reaſon to fear they may be many. Read the threatning and warning, Levit, 26.31, 34.
I will make your Cities waſte and bring your Sanctuaries into deſolation, and ſcatter you among your Enemies; then ſhall the land enjoy her Sabbaths; as long as it lieth deſolate it ſhall reſt, becauſe ye did not reſt in your Sabbaths when ye dwelt in it. All this was fulfilled in the doleful ſeventy years Captivity of the Jews in Babylon. Then the Holy Land enjoy'd a long and ſad reſt, without a worſhipper or place of worſhip. See the 2. Cron 36.20, 21. And they burnt the houſe of God, and brake down the wall of Jeruſalem, and carried away the Remnant to Babylon, to fulfil the Word of the Lord, until the Land enjoy'd her Sabbaths. We read alſo how that when the Jews were return'd from Babylon, and again fell into this Sin, Nehemiah told them that the paſt wrath had been provok'd by this, and that more would ſtill be ſo: Nehem. 13.17, 18. Did not your fathers thus? and did not our God bring all this Evil upon us, and upon this City? Yet ye bring more wrath upon Iſrael by profaning the Sabbath.
BUT this for the fifth head, That from the beginning God did very dreadfully threaten and terribly puniſh the violation of the Sabbath.

VI. THE holy Prophets of the Lord did in their times vehemently inſiſt on the ſanctification of the Lords Sabbaths; they complain'd of and declared againſt the profanation of it, and they made in God's name the moſt gracious Promiſes to the people of God in caſe of their religious Obſervation thereof. Theſe three things, added unto what I have ſaid before, will give you the whole voice of Scripture thro' the Old Teſtament of the ſanctification of of the Sabbath-day.

1. I ſay, The Holy Prophets of God did in their times vehemently inſiſt on the keeping God's Sabbaths. I ſcarce know a ſtricter precept and fuller direction in this point thro' the whole Book of God, than thoſe words of the Prophet Iſaiah, the 58. Chap. and 13. v. If thou turn away thy foot from the Sabbath, from doing thy pleaſure on my holy day, and call the Sabbath a delight, the Holy of the Lord, honourable, and ſhalt honour him; not doing thine own ways, nor finding thine own pleaſure, nor ſpeaking thine own words. Here the Prophet taught the people of God how to Sabbatize, and requir'd them ſo to keep the Sabbath; and his words are written for our admonition and learning.

list.item: 1. WE muſt turn away our foot from the Sabbath: from trampling on it, (ſays a late pious Expoſitor) as profane, atheiſtical people do; from travelling on it, as many worldly men are ready to do; and from thoſe walks and diverſions on it, which men of pleaſure and licence are apt to take.

2. WE muſt not do our own ways, nor find our own pleaſure on God's holy day. We muſt not follow our Callings, which is to do our own ways; nor follow our ſports and recreations, which is to find our own pleaſures. Eſpecially we muſt beware of the defiling and polluting pleaſures of ſin, which are unlawful on any day.

3. WE muſt not ſpeak our own words: Not give our ſelves that liberty of ſpeech on the Sabbath day, which we may lawfully take on other days. Our words muſt be then guarded, grave, and ſeaſoned with grace. We muſt ſpeak God's
word; ſpeak of Him and of his Works, out of his Word: not talk of our worldly affairs and buſineſs as on other days.

4. IT muſt be honourable to us becauſe the holy of the Lord. The holy duties of it ſhould be pleaſant and delightful to us. We muſt honour it as the Lord's day; the day which the Lord has made; made for himſelf, and ſanctified to his honour and ſervice; made ſacred to us, and to be ſpent in holy duties: We will rejoyce and be glad in it. Pſal. 118.24.

div.p: AFTER this manner Iſaiah preſcribes and requires the keeping a Sabbath: how ſpiritual and reverend! and thus from one Sabbath to another ſhould all fleſh come and worſhip before the Lord. Iſai. 66.23.

LET us paſs on to the Prophecies of Jeremiah, and obſerve how he alſo inſiſts on the Sanctification of the Sabbath. Jer. 17.20, 22. Hear ye the word of the Lord ye Kings of Judah, and all the Inhabitants of Jeruſalem that enter in by theſe gates; thus ſaith the Lord, Take heed to your ſelves and bear no burden on the Sabbath day, nor bring it in by the Gates of Jeruſalem; neither do ye any work, but hallow the Sabbath day as I commanded your Fathers. This Commandment was to the King and all the people together: The higheſt and loweſt are equally under this Law and muſt be obedient. And to the Rulers it belongs to ſee to it that the Sabbath be ſanctified by their People.

A like Order both to Prince and peaſant, for the religious obſervation of the Sabbath we have from the pen of the prophet Ezehiel, 46. Chap. 1,2. The Gate of the inner Court that looketh toward
the Eaſt ſhall be ſhut the ſix working days; but on the Sabbath it ſhall be opened, and the Prince ſhall enter by it,— and the Prieſt ſhall prepare his burnt-offering,— and he ſhall worſhip at the threſhold of the Gate,— and it ſhall not be ſhut until the Evening. It is the duty of Princes, and it is the priviledge of peaſants, to go up to the Sanctuary of God on his Sabbaths, then and there to worſhip him with holy reverence, as unworthy to tread the threſhold of his Gates.

IN this frame and ſpirit we find Nehemiah, and the Princes, Prieſts and Levites with him, ſigning a Covenant to walk in the Laws of God and to keep his Sabbath. Nehem 10.31. We cannot walk in God's laws and not keep his Sabbaths; In our Covenanting with God to walk in his laws, we do in a ſpecial manner covenant to keep his Sabbaths. This is a ſpecial Article in God's Covenant with his People.
THUS have the Holy prophets inſiſted on the Obſervation of the Sabbath in their days and times.

2. THEY complain'd grievouſly of the profanation of it. For this they had too often ſad occaſion. What evil thing is this that ye do? ſaid holy Nehemiah to the people of his day;— Ye profane the Sabbath day. It griev'd the good Governour to the heart to ſee it. He called it a moſt evil thing. He ſpake of it with a pious anger and indignation, to ſee God ſo diſhonoured; and with a holy fear of the Conſequence of ſuch a provocation. In like manner the Prophets, Ezekiel and Amos. Ezek. 22.8. Thou haſt deſpiſed my holy things, and haſt profaned my Sabbaths. 20.13. My
Sabbaths they greatly polluted, then I ſaid I would pour out my fury upon them to conſume them. Amos 8.5, 8. Shall not the Land tremble for this? and every one mourn that dwelleth therein? and will not the end thereof be as a bitter day?— It is a ſorrowful and fearful Symptom, when peeople are ſick of their Sabbaths; weary of the ſacred reſt, and tir'd with the holy work.— But on the contrary, and to add no more,

3. THE Prophets of the Lord have made many great and precious Promiſes to the people of God, in caſe of their religious Obſervation of the Holy Sabbath. The God who has bleſſed the ſeventh day and put his Name upon it, will bleſs all them that keep it holy. Spiritual Bleſſings are the ſpecial and more natural fruit of Sabbath Sanctification; but the outward bleſſings of Providence are alſo the reward of it. This is the way to enſure the ſpiritual and temporal Bleſſing together. Iſai. 56.2. Bleſſed is the man that doeth this, that keepeth the Sabbath from polluting it. This brings a bleſſing on all our imployments, but eſpecially upon our Souls. Here then,

1. THE ſpiritual Bleſſing, yea all ſpiritual bleſſings in heavenly places, is the promiſe to the Perſon that keeps God's Sabbaths. Iſai. 56.4, 5, 6. For thus ſaith the Lord to them that keep my Sabbaths, and chooſe the things that pleaſe me, and take hold of my Covenant; even to them will I give in my Houſe and within my Walls, a place and a name better than of Sons and Daughters; I will give them an everlaſting name that ſhall not be cut off:— I will bring them to my holy mountain, and make them joyful in
my houſe of prayer; their burnt-offerings and their Sacrifices ſhall be accepted upon mine Altar.

NOTE here, That theſe three things go together; the religious Obſervation of the Sabbath, the Chooſing the things that pleaſe God, and the taking hold of his Covenant. Look where you will and ſhew me one that keeps God's Sabbaths, and you ſhall find him one that in all other points likewiſe chuſes the things that pleaſe him; And ſuch may and will and do lay hold of God's Covenant. It is from a ſincere univerſal deſire of pleaſing God and glorifying him, that the pious worſhippers of God ſet themſelves to obſerve and keep his Sabbaths. Such have (thro' grace) conſented and come up to the Terms of God's Covenant, have taken him for their God, his Word for their Rule, and given themſelves up to him, in his holy ways and among his people.

AND now how great and precious are the Promiſes made here to this holy Sabbatizer? even all the Bleſſings of the Covenant of Grace are aſſured to him; preſent peace and communion with God and ſupplies of Grace, and the everlaſting love and mercies of our Heavenly Father. They have a Name among the Children of God, a Name in the Church on earth, a Name written in Heaven; an everlaſting Name that ſhall not be cut off.— Thus the Spiritual Bleſſing is the Promiſe to the perſon that keeps God's Sabbaths. And then

2. THE Temporal bleſſing is promiſed to the People that do this. To prove this I need only turn you again to the 58. Iſai. 13, 14. If thou call
the Sabbath a delight, &c Then ſhalt thou delight thy ſelf in the Lord, and I will cauſe thee to ride upon the high places of the earth, and feed thee with the Heritage of Jacob thy father; for the mouth of the Lord hath ſpoken it. Here are the temporal Rewards; even riches, honour, power, ſafety, proſperity and dignity; to the place and people, the Country or Nation, that keep God's Sabbaths.

GOD promis'd his Iſrael that he wou'd make them high in Name and honour, if they ſought his honour and obſerv'd his will; and that their Nei'bours ſhould ſee him bleſs them. He promiſed them to feed 'em, to defend 'em, and to advance 'em. He promis'd that if they would zealouſly and religiouſly keep his appointed Feaſts, no man ſhould deſire their Land when they went up unto 'em. He alſo bid them prove him, if he did not open the Heavens over them to pour down Bleſſings, if they duly regarded his Worſhip and Sanctuary. And doubtleſs this will always commend a People to his favour and bleſſing in the courſe of his Providence; and he will be their ſhield and ſtrength, and the lifter up of their head.

IN a Word, We have the promiſe and the threatning repeated, the Bleſſing and the Curſe; Jer. 17.24, 25, 27. And it ſhall some to paſs if ye diligently hearken to me, ſaith the Lord, to bring in no burden thro' the gates of this City on the Sabbath day; but if ye hallow the ſame;— then ſhall there enter ſtill into it Kings and Princes ſitting upon the Throne of David, riding in Chariots and on horſes; and this City ſhall remain for ever; and burnt-offerings and ſacrifices, meat-offerings and Incenſe of praiſe,
ſhall ſtill be in the houſe of the Lord:— But if ye will not hearken unto me, to hallow the Sabbath day, then I will kindle a fire in the Gates of Jeruſalem, which ſhall devour its palaces, (whereof the Temple was a principal one) and it ſhall not he quenched.—That is to ſay,

THE religious Sanctification of God's Sabbaths would have been a means of preſerving the Royal Houſe of David, and the Holy City of God; But for the profanation of the Sabbath both the one and the other were bro't to ruine. The prophet aſſured them from God, that in caſe they would keep his Day, He would keep the Court, the City, the Country and the Church, and make all to flouriſh: But on the contrary, if they went on to profane the Lord's Sabbaths, the Lord would deſtroy them all together. And ſo it was: The Enemy prevailed againſt Jeruſalem, and kindled a fire in the Gates of the City, which burnt down the Palace of the King and the Temple of God, and none could quench it.
AND thus I have ſhewn thro' Moſes and the Prophets, how ſtrictly and vehemently the Holy God has required and inculcated the Sanctification of the Sabbath day.

WHICH was the thing to be prov'd,— Verily my Sabbaths ye ſhall keep. The Inſtances given, from the precept to Adam unto and by the laſt of the Prophets, are ſo many plain and affecting proofs, as well as ſingular Illuſtrations, of my Doctrine. The method which I have taken is, I think, the moſt ſimple and natural Expoſition of what the Scripture has ſaid upon this head, ſo far as I have gone.— God bleſs what we have heard for
the Increaſing in us the Reverence of his Holy Day, the ſtrict Obſervation of it, and the fear of profaning it. Amen.

div.head: Sermon Second.

q.p: And the Lord ſpake unto Moſes, ſaying, Speak thou alſo unto the Children of Iſrael, ſaying,
Verily my Sabbaths ye ſhall keep; for it is a ſign between me and you thro'out your Generations; that ye may know that I am the Lord that doth ſanctify you.

div.p: THE great Law of the Sabbath is here repeated to Moſes, and by him unto the Children of Iſrael with an awful Preface, in a moſt commanding Manner, and with a moſt powerful Reaſon annexed. More Authority and Commandment can't be well put into fewer words.

THE laſt time I ſpake in this place, I propoſed to ſpeak to theſe two Doctrines. I. That the Great GOD has moſt ſtrictly and vehemently required the Sanctification of the Sabbath day. II. That it is a ſign between Him and us that he is the Lord that doth ſanctify us.
I cou'd not quite get thro' the firſt Doctrine on the laſt Lecture, namely,

I. D. THAT the Lord our God has moſt ſtrictly and vehemently required us to keep his Sabbaths. Verily my Sabbaths ye ſhall keep.— It was a Law to Man from the beginning of the World, and the firſt Law that was given to him, even in his ſtate of Innocence. It was one of the firſt things given in Commandment to Iſrael upon their leaving Egypt. It was one of the ten Words, the ten Commandments, given from Sinai, in that auguſt and fearful manner. It was repeated and inculcated upon the delivery of the Ceremonial and Judicial Law, and was indeed inſerted into the latter. Moreover. God has from the beginning very dreadfully threatned and terribly puniſhed the violation of this Commandment. And by the mouth of all his Holy Prophets he has vehemently inſiſted on the Sanctification of the Sabbath day, complained of and declar'd againſt the profanation of it; and they have made in God's name the moſt gracious promiſes to the people of God in caſe of their religious Obſervation thereof.— Thus thro' the Scriptures of the Old Teſtament we find abundant proofs and plain Illuſtrations of our Doctrine.

I ſhall continue the proof of this great Truth thro' the Scriptures of the New Teſtament. The religious
and ſtrict Obſervation of the Lord's day is there alſo directed to, preſcribed and enjoyned; but more by the holy practice and example of our Lord Jeſus and his Apoſtles, than by precepts.

THE Law of a Sabbath was nothing peculiar to the Jewiſh Church. It was before them, even a Law from the beginning of the world, and it continues after them, unto the End of time. There remaineth the keeping of a Sabbath to the people of God, and it will do ſo while the world laſts. The Law is Moral, and of perpetual Uſe, univerſal Obligation. We need the priviledge of a Sabbath now, its uſe and benefit to our Souls; as much as the People of God did heretofore: And we owe this homage, honour and ſervice to God as much now as his People of old did. A weekly Sabbath is a ſmall rent and acknowledgement unto the LORD of our lives, in whoſe hand all our time is.

LET us look into the holy Goſpels, the Acts of the Apoſtles, the Epiſtles of Paul, and the Revelations of John, and read the mind of Chriſt reſpecting the religious Obſervation of the Sabbathday. And let us bear in mind that the Practice of Chriſt and his Apoſtles is a Law to us in this matter. For (as a late worthy Writer
Mr. Wright on the religious Obſervation of the Lord's-Day. has it) Actions do certainly make a Law, where they ſufficiently publiſh the Mind and Will of the Lawgiver, as much as words. If then we can find Actions of our Lord Jeſus, and of his Apoſtles after him, equivalent to a verbal Precept, for the Obſervation of the Chriſtian Shbbath, we muſt
needs account it his Inſtitution and Commandment to us.

IN the bleſſed Life of our Saviour we read once and again of his going into the Synagogues, to attend the publick Worſhip of God on the Sabbath days. Luke 4.6. As his Cuſtom was he went into the Synagogue on the Sabbath day. This he did to teach and require us to keep the Sabbath as he did. He has given us this Example that we ſhould follow his ſteps. So he ſerv'd and worſhip'd God, fulfilling all Righteouſneſs, and ſo muſt we. He came not to deſtroy the Law and the Prophets, but to fulfil them. Had he put an end to the Sacred weekly Sabbath, it had deſtroyed the Law and the Prophets with a witneſs. But Chriſt fulfilled this Law, and kept many a Sabbath to the glory of God in a perfect manner, ſo as no meer man, nor all the Holy men of God together, ever did or can do. He has taught us how to Sabbatiſe; how to ſpend our Sabbaths in the ſolemn Aſſemblies, and in works of piety and mercy. Many a high Exerciſe of devotion, and many a good work of charity, did he upon the Sabbath-day. He fill'd up the Holy time with work, and the work with Spirit. For theſe very works of God like goodneſs he was ſometimes reproached as a breaker of the Sabbath; but it turn'd to the confuſion of his ignorant and ſuperſtitious, if not hypocritical and malicious Accuſers. As in Mark 3. Init. He ſanctified and honour'd the Sabbath by his divine Sermons, and by his miracles of mercy on that bleſſed day. He made it a Day of his Bleſſing to men, both on temporal and ſpiritual accounts. Luk. 13.10, 17.
He kept that bleſſed Law for his Elect, which Believers themſelves keep ſo poorly and imperfectly.— He alſo taught his Diſciples and followers to obſerve and keep the Sabbath-day, Indeed ſome of the ſuperſtitious Phariſees did ſometimes tax the Diſciples with taking undue liberties on the Holy Sabbath. But what was it? they plucked an ear of corn and eat of it as they paſſed thro' a field. They were hungry and it was but a proper and needed taſte, and an ordinary haſty bit, for their ſupport and refreſhment in the ſervices of the day. The Women alſo that followed our Lord Jeſus, and miniſtred unto him, were ſtrict Sabbatizers: Luk. 23. ult. They reſted on the Sabbath day according to the Commandment. Tho' they were preparing ſpices for the dead body of their dear Saviour, yet they laid by the holy care and labour of love till the Sabbath was over. Verily God's Sabbaths did they keep; even as if the words of my Text were then in their remembrance, and they conſidered that as the holy work of the Tabernacle was to give place to the holy Reſt of God's day, ſo their pious miniſtring to that ſacred Temple of the Deity, our Lords Body.— And that was the laſt Seventh day Sabbath which the Diſciples kept. For early in the morning of the next day, being the firſt day of the week theſe Women came unto the Sepulchre, bringing the Spices which they had prepared;See Luk. 24.1, 13, 34, 36. And John 20.1, 16, 19, 26. and they found not the Body of Jeſus, but had a viſion of Angels who told them of his reſurrection from the dead.— And that ſame day the Lord himſelf
appeared ſeveral times to one and another of his Followers; to Mary Magdalene, to the two diſciples on their way to Emmaus, to Simon, and to the ten together in the Evening: when he bleſſed them, breathed on 'em, and gave them their Commiſſion. That day ſeven night, being again the firſt day of the week, the Lord appeared again unto them, Thomas being then preſent, and ſhewed them his hands and his feet.— Now by the Reſurrection of Chriſt on the firſt day of the week, and by his repeated viſits to them on this day, the Inſpired Apoſtles (under the infallible Conduct of the Holy Ghoſt) from thenceforth held their ſolemn Meetings, their holy Convocations, on this day of the ſeven, and called it the Lord's-Day.— On this firſt day of the week, the Diſciples were all with one accord in one place, Act. 1.1, 2. aſſembled as on their holy Sabbath, when ſuddenly there appeared the cloven Tongues of fire and ſat upon them, and they were all filled with the Holy Ghoſt; and ſpake in every language the wonderful works of God; the proper ſervice of the Sabbath day. That this day of Pentecoſt was the firſt day of the week is eaſily computed and proved. The day after the Paſſover was the firſt day of the feaſt of unleavened bread; (ſee Lev. 23.5, 6.) which was as a Sabbath to the Jews; They were to have an holy Convocation on it, and to do no ſervile work thereon. On the next day was the Offering of the firſt-fruits unto the Lord: And from this day, (the next but one after the Paſſover) they were order'd to count fifty days, or ſeven weeks complete; and
then was the feaſt of Pentecoſt, ſo called from the fiftieth day. Now ſee how theſe things were all fulfilled in the Dying and Reſurrection of our Lord Jeſus, and in the pouring out of the Spirit on the day of Pentecoſt.— Our bleſſed Lord Jeſus was ſlain at the Paſſover, which fell that year on a fryday: Then was the Lamb of God offered, Chriſt our Paſſover ſacrificed for us.— That Evening therefore was the preparation, as it is called John 19.31. ſcil. the preparation both for the weekly Sabbath, and alſo for the Feaſt of unleavened bread; which made that Sabbath a high day. The Jews therefore were earneſt with Pilate to have the Bodies taken down early from the Croſs. This whole Sabbath our Lord's Body lay in the grave. And the next morning early, being the firſt day of the week, the next day but one after the Paſſover, the day of the offering of the firſt-fruits unto the Lord, he roſe from the dead, and became the firſt-fruits of them that ſleep. Now compute juſt ſeven weeks from this day of our Lord's Reſurrection, and the firſt day of the eighth week, even the fiftieth day, was the day of Pentecoſt; when the Spirit, (the promiſe of the Father) was pour'd out from the aſcended Jeſus upon his Apoſtles, as they were aſſembled together for his ſolemn Worſhip. Then (as one ſays) they themſelves received the firſt-fruits of the Spirit, and thro' the word of truth begat three thouſand ſouls to Chriſt; and preſented them as the firſt-fruits of the Chriſtian Church unto God and to the Lamb. Thus did our Lord Jeſus honour and hallow the firſt day of the week by giving the Sanctifier and the Comforter thereon. So did he ſhed Him forth in his
miraculous Gifts and in his ſaving Graces, abundantly on that day. He poured out the Bleſſing from on high, and bleſſed the Day, to be an holy Sabbath unto Himſelf; and unto us, the day for our "ſeeking and receiving ſpiritual bleſſings. Such Actions (ſays One) do as fully declare and expreſs the mind and will of Heaven as any words could do— Eſpecially if we find (as we do) in the ſacred Writings, that the Apoſtles and primitive Chriſtians did thenceforth obſerve the firſt day of the week for their religious Aſſemblies, and for the Adminiſtration of the ſpecial Ordinances of Chriſt thereon. And this we do expreſly read, that they did come together on the firſt day of the week to break bread, and that Paul preached to them. Act. 20.7. They were wont to come together to hear and to receive the Sacrament of the Lord's Supper, on that day. It is ſpoken of as their uſual practice, and they were "under the infallible Direction of the Holy Ghoſt in Actions of this nature and importance. So that their Example and practice herein muſt amount to a Law and Inſtitution to the Chriſtian Church; interpreting to us the mind and giving us the will of Chriſt in this matter. And to borrow the words of a late Writer, As Moſes was faithful in ſettling the matters of the Jewiſh worſhip and of the Tabernacle, being authoriſed by God and guided by him in the doing it; ſo the Apoſtles were to ſettle the Orders of the Goſpel Church, and were faithful to Him who appointed them— Moreover you know, how that the Apoſtle Paul directed the Church of Corinth, and the Churches of Galatia, to have their Collections
for the Saints on the firſt day of the week; So (ſays he) I have given order, and ſo do ye: Upon the firſt day of the week let every one lay by him in ſtore, as God has proſpered him. 1 Cor. 16.1, 2. — Some have obſerved, and the remark is of great weight, That the firſt day of the week is the only day ſpoken of thro' the New Teſtament, as a day religiouſly obſerved; but that this day is ſeveral times over ſo ſpoken of. A day ſacred in the Apoſtles times for Holy fellowſhip and communion, for breaking of bread and for prayers, and for works of piety and charity; for the publick teſtimony of their faith in Chriſt and love to all his Saints.— To add no more, They called it the Lord's-day; and on it the beloved Diſciple had his Viſion of Chriſt, one like the ſon of man amidſt the ſeven golden Candleſticks. Rev. 1.10. I was in the Spirit (in a ſpiritual Extaſie or Rapture) on the Lord's day. Whoſe day?Ubi Johannes dicit ſe raptum fuiſſe in Spiritu Die Dominico; non ſane Sabbatho Judaeorum, quod procul dubio nominaſſet; non aliquo tantum die Septimanae, quia ſic ambiguus eſſet titulus, ad implicandum potius quam explicandum comparatus, ſed die illo quo Chriſtus reſurrexerat, quo convenire ſolebant Apoſtoli ad ſacra peragenda, et quo Paulus ordinaverat collectas haben • as, prout moris erat in primitiva Eccleſia. Cum ergo de illo die tanquam nota et in Eccleſia uſitata loquitur, dubium non eſt quin ex recepto Eccleſiae uſu hoc nomine inſignita ſit. Turret. Vol. 2, p. 103. but the Lord Jeſus, whoſe Revelations he now received. And aſſign a reaſon, if you can, for another day of the week, to be called his, beſides the firſt, whereon he roſe from the dead. As the Sacrament of the body and blood of Chriſt is
called the Lord's Supper, ſo is the Chriſtian Sabbath the Lord's day. Both the one and other are inſtituted, ſeparated and appropriated unto his worſhip, and the religious remembrance of Himſelf.— The Son of man is Lord of the Sabbath, Lord of our time and lives. He has power to change the day. And there is the ſame reaſon why it ſhould pleaſe the Lord Redeemer to take the firſt day of the week for his own day, and make it the weekly Sabbath to the Church, upon his Reſurrection thereon from the dead; as there was why the Lord Creator pleaſed to bleſs the ſeventh day, and the ſeventh part of time, becauſe he reſted from his work of Creation after ſix days. For the work of mans Redemption is a work of God equally glorious with that of his Creation, and ſo equally worthy of a ſacred, inſtituted, perpetual Memorial. And the reſurrection of Chriſt was really his reſting from his work of our redemption, having compleated it in his death. Nor does the change of the day of the week in the leaſt take away from the Memorial of the Work of Creation every Sabbath day; for the ſeventh part of time is yet ſacredly obſerved in Commemoration thereof.— Upon all therefore, We have now the ſame Reaſons for our religious Obſervation of the firſt day of the week, that the Church of old had for their keeping holy the ſeventh day. The reaſons to them were, God's ſpecial propriety in the ſeventh day, his own Example and reſting thereon, and his bleſſing it. And for theſe reaſons we keep the firſt day of the week holy to Chriſt, becauſe of his ſpecial propriety therein, (his reſting on it, and taking it for his
own) his own Example and his bleſſing it. On every Account it is the Lord's day, the Chriſtian Sabbath.— Jeſus has given us this Reſt, upon his ceaſing from his redeeming work as God did from his of Creation; and upon his entring into his reſt. There remaineth therefore a Reſt to the people of God; a ſpiritual reſt in Chriſt, and the keeping of a weekly Sabbath to him.

AND thus I have briefly traced thro' the Scriptures of the New Teſtament, ſome of the things occurring there, for our keeping holy the Sabbath-day.— And ſo I diſmiſs the firſt part of my Text, Verily my Sabbaths ye ſhall keep.— I come now to the Reaſon annexed, which is the other part, For it is a Sign between me and you thro'out your Generations, that I am the Lord that doth ſanctify you.
2. D. THAT the Lord's-day, or weekly Sabbath, is a Sign between God and us, that he is the Lord our Sanctifier.

IT is great Condeſcention and Grace in God to us, to annex a reaſon unto any of his Commandments. His Sovereign will is the higheſt reaſon.— Yet is there much of Majeſty and much Grace in this Reaſon, It is a Sign between me and you. And will God in very deed give us ſuch a Sign and Token between Himſelf and us? will he in very deed deal ſo with Man upon the Earth? And give a ſtanding Sign too, thro'out all the Generations of men on earth? O the favour and Grace to duſt and aſhes! while He humbleth himſelf to behold the things that are above!

BUT what is the Lord's Sabbaths a Sign of thro' all the Generations of men? Why they ſignify and let us know, 1. That he is the Lord and our Lord: Lord of the world, and Lord of our time and lives. The great Proprietor and abſolute Diſpoſer of them. 2. That he is the Lord our Sanctifier. This is that Glory wherein he delights to appear unto his Creatures, and for which to be adored by them. So the Seraphims worſhip him above, and cover their faces, crying, Holy, Holy, Holy is the Lord of Hoſts. And ſo we worſhip the Lord in the Beauties of Holineſs on earth; His Sabbaths being unto us the ſign, and his Ordinances the bleſſed means of holineſs and Sanctification.

THE Lord our Sanctifier. It ſpeaks the utmoſt favour, grace and mercy to us, and the utmoſt holineſs in the Lord our God. He is the Sanctifier of all whom he ſaves. His Elect are choſen unto Salvation thro' ſanctification of the Spirit. And he has appointed his Holy Sabbath and all the Ordinances of his worſhip, under the bleſſing of his Spirit, to be the ſeaſon and means of the Regeneration and Sanctification of ſouls, and of their growth and increaſe in Holineſs.

GOD's Sabbaths were from the beginning of the world given for a Sign and a Memorial. They are a Sign that in ſix days the Lord made Heaven and earth— Our Lord's days are now a Sign of the Reſurrection of Chriſt from the dead. And in ſhort, both the Jewiſh and Chriſtian Sabbath are a Sign to fallen man, of a Covenant of Grace and Salvation granted to him thro' Jeſus Chriſt; the promiſed ſeed of the Woman, but the Only Begotten of the Eternal Father.

TO be ſure, The Obſervation of a weekly Sabbath is a very public and open thing; a thing of much Solemnity and Significancy. It is a perpetual and univerſal Memorial of ſomething very great and important between God and man.— Every child is ready to ask, What meaneth this Service? what ſignifies ſuch a weekly Solemnity? —God anſwers in my Text, It is a ſign between Me and you. Surely then a ſign of ſomething very great and good on God's part, and worthy of his bleſſed and glorious Name, and of ſomething very good and great, beneficial and neceſſary to us! Yes truly: the work and grace is great on God's part, to be our Sanctifier! the benefit and mercy vaſt to us, our Sanctification!— This, this is ſignified by the weekly Sabbath. What more worthy of the Holy God? what more important to polluted, guilty and periſhing Sinners? Of his mercy he thus ſaves us.

THE Text ſpeaks plainly of two things,
1. Of a Covenant between God and fallen man: It is a Sign between me and you thro' out your Generations.
2. Of a Covenant of holineſs, or of our Salvation in a way of Sanctification; that I am the Lord that ſanctifieth you. Therefore theſe two things lie before me,
1. To ſhow that the Lord's Sabbaths continued to fallen man, are a ſign and token of the Covenant of Grace made with him thro' Jeſus Chriſt.
2. It is a ſign and token of Chriſts ſaving us in the way of Holineſs or Sanctification.

1. THE Lord's Sabbaths continued to fallen man, are a ſign and token of the Covenant of Grace made with him in Jeſus Chriſt. It is a ſign between 〈◊〉 and you. Here is ſomething mutual between 〈◊〉 parties, God and man; ſignificant of great grace and favour to man on the part of God, and of ſpecial and holy bonds and duty to God on the part of man; Now what can this be but a faderal and Covenant ſtipulation? and what can it be referred unto, but only the Covenant of Grace and Salvation by Jeſus Chriſt? Aſſign ſomething elſe if you can.

INDEED the Sabbath was given and inſtituted to Man in his State of Innocence, and that even before the Covenant of works was given unto Adam. But Man having ſinned and broken the firſt Covenant, had forfeited and loſt the Priviledge and honour of a Sabbath. There remained no room or place for any Sabbath to him till it was reſtored in the Covenant of Grace.— But as it pleaſed God, according to his Eternal Counſel and purpoſe, immediately to reveal unto fallen man hss Covenant of Grace and Salvation, thro' Jeſus Chriſt the promiſed Seed of the Woman; So the Law of the Sabbath did naturally and in courſe revive and take place again.— For it is nothing peculiar either to the Covenant of Grace, or to the Covenant of works, that there ſhould be a Sabbath; but it muſt needs be common to either, that there be ſome appointed time ſacred unto the public and
ſolemn worſhip of God.— IF then God pleaſed to give a new Covenant to Man after his fall, it muſt needs bring him a new Right and liberty to worſhip God; and conſequently muſt revive the Priviledge and Law of a Sabbath to him.— And other Foundation can no man lay, for this priviledge and liberty of Worſhip, than this which is laid, Jeſus Chriſt, and the Covenant of Grace in and thro' him. It is truly one of the Benefits of Redemption, and a great and neceſſary one. It is the Gift of Grace by Jeſus Chriſt; it is the purchaſe of his Death, and the fruit of his Reſurrection, that there remaineth the keeping of a Sabbath to the Children of fallen Adam.— This is a Benefit of the New Covenant, without which there had remained no place for prayer, praiſe or worſhip to fallen man; and conſequently no day ſacred to theſe Duties.

HENCE the Sabbath is ſaid to be given for a Covenant, and to be obſerved as ſuch; and the ten Commandments are called God's Covenant: Deu. 4.13. He declared unto you his Covenant; even ten Commandments. But it is the fourth Commandment which ſtands peculiarly as the moſt viſible token of the Covenant of God; according to the 16. v. of our Context, Ye ſhall obſerve the Sabbath for a perpetual Covenant. And Ezek. 20.20. It is a ſign between me and you, that I am the Lord your God.— Every Sabbath day we do publickly and ſolemnly confeſs and avouch the Lord Jehovah to be the true God, and
God alone, and that he is our God and Redeemer, and that we are his people and worſhippers, and will be devoted to him for ever. Theſe two things are therefore put together by the Holy Ghoſt, Iſa. 56.4, 6. The keeping God's Sabbaths, the taking hold of his Covenant, and the joyning our ſelves unto the Lord.— We keep God's Sabbaths as a ſign of our faith in and devotion to the God of Iſrael, as the great Creator and High Poſſeſſor of heaven and earth. According to what we read in my Context, v. 17. It is ſign between Me and the Children of Iſrael for ever, that in ſix days the Lord made all things, and in the ſeventh he reſted and was refreſhed.— Again, We covenant with God thro' Chriſt, as the Lord our Redeemer, in our keeping his Sabbaths. It was to the Church of Iſrael, and is to the Chriſtian Church, a Memorial of redeeming Grace and Mercy. When God had redeemed Iſrael out of Egypt, he then ſaid to them, Deut. 5.15. Remember that thou waſt a Servant there, and that the Lord thy God bro't thee out thence with a ſtrong hand and by a ſtretched out arm; Therefore the Lord thy God commanded thee to keep the Sabbath day. Here was a ſuper-added and ſpecial reaſon to Iſrael for their religious obſervation of the Sabbath. Some learned men have argued and inſiſted on it, that the ſeventh day from the Overthrow of Pharaoh at the Red Sea was the Jewiſh Sabbath. And if it were ſo yet might it be the ſeventh day from the Creation alſo. But to be ſure, in memory of this their Redemption, as well as of the World's
Creation, they were to keep their Sabbaths.— Now this ſeems to me a plain Prefiguration of our Chriſtian Sabbath, in memory of Chriſt's finiſhing the work of our Redemption. For if the Sabbath was unto the Jews a ſign of their Covenant relation and obligations to God as their Saviour and Redeemer; is it not more ſo unto us under the Goſpel, and from the day of the completion of the Spiritual and Eternal Redemption by the Son of God? If that deliverance which was but the Type came into a conſtant Remembrance, and was a ſtanding reaſon of the weekly Sabbath till the Reſurrection of Chriſt; ſhall not the Eternal Redemption by Him, which is the Subſtance, be had in a perpetual Remembrance by us upon the weekly Sabbath; and be a ſpecial reaſon to us for our Sanctifying the ſame?— Wherefore no doubt but from the fall of Man unto the End of the world, the Sabbath has been ordained, and by the worſhippers of God ought to be obſerved, in memory of Man's Redemption as well as of his Creation, and to the honour of God our Redeemer as well as Creator; and ſo we keep it, as a redeemed people, bought with his Blood; and every Lord's-day we covenant anew with our Saviour, to glorify him in our bodies and ſpirits which are his.— The Covenant ſtands for ever, becauſe the Redeemer liveth, therefore the Sabbath abides: The Covenant of his peace is not removed, and the God of the whole Earth is he called, who is the Holy One of Iſrael, the Redeemer.— God openly and
ſignificantly covenants with his Church and people every Sabbath day. He meets them to bleſs 'em, as they aſſemble to worſhip him. He gives a name and place within his walls, even an everlaſting name. He does this (ſays the Prophet) Iſa. 56.6. while we joyn our ſelves unto him, to ſerve him and to love his Name.— Wherefore God owns his people, as well as they him, every Lord's-day. He meets them in his own appointed time and ways. He ſeals to his Covenant, and ſhews it to them, and his ſecret is with them while they keep his Sabbath.— The riſen Saviour viſits his aſſembled Diſciples from week to week, and is ſtill in the midſt of them, and ſays, peace be unto you; yea and ſhews them his hands and his feet when they come together to break bread.— Thus the Sabbath is the abiding and conſpicuous Sign of a Church ſtate; and it is for Stipulation and mutual Covenanting between God and his people.— It is a ſign between Me and you.

2. It is an evident token, and bleſſed means, of Man's Salvation in a way of holineſs and ſanctification. That I am the Lord that ſanctifieth you. A parallel place we have, Ezek. 20.12. Moreover alſo I gave them my Sabbaths to be a Sign between me and them, that they might know that I am the Lord that doth ſanctify them.— This, this is at laſt the thing ſignified, the thing covenanted. God covenants with his people to be their Sanctifier in their obſervation of his Sabbaths; they covenant to be holy to him and
to ſeek his ſanctifying grace, and live as his ſanctified Ones.

GOD's Sabbaths were to the Jews a ſign of his ſelecting them from other people and conſecrating them unto himſelf, his worſhip and ſervice; to be unto him as a kingdom of prieſts, a holy nation. If he had not ſo ſet 'em apart for himſelf, he would not have revealed to them his Sabbaths, to ſet up his Worſhip among them: And they that worſhip him muſt be ſanctified, muſt ſanctify themſelves hereunto.

MOREOVER, The Obſervation of the Sabbath ever was, is and will be, a ſpecial means of the Sanctification of God's Elect. He ſanctifies them by his Spirit in his Word and Ordinances, the Means of grace and holineſs, wherein his Sabbaths are ſanctified, and wherein his people apply to him as their Sanctifier. If we keep God's days, they will be the means of our ſanctification. It is a ſign that God has ſanctified us if we love his Sabbaths; and to keep them is the grand means of our increaſe in holineſs.

THUS the Holy Sabbaths of God do exhibit him unto us, not only as the Lord our Creator and Redeemer, but alſo as the Lord our Sanctifier. Not only is the Sabbath ordained to ſerve unto the honour and worſhip of God the Father Almighty, Maker of Heaven and Earth; and of Jeſus Chriſt his only Son our Saviour, but alſo
of the Holy Ghoſt (proceeding from the Father and the Son) our Sanctifier.

SANCTIFICATION is the ſpecial work of the Holy and Eternal Spirit of God. In remembrance of his glorious deſcent from the Aſcended Saviour we keep our Lord's days. He is in his Word and Ordinances, the which he has inſpired and inſtituted, and makes them the effectual means of holineſs unto all ſincere and fervent Worſhippers.

HE is himſelf the Holy One, infinitly holy. He would have us holy. He only can make us ſo. His Sabbaths and worſhip are holy, and ſanctifying to us. We wait on him in them for his ſanctifying influences and Operations. He bleſſes his Sabbaths and Inſtitutions for this end. He ſanctifies his Elect thro' his Truth, his Word is the Truth. We acknowledge him as the Lord our Sanctifier, apply to him and glorify him as ſuch, in the way of Sabbath Sanctification. And they that do ſo, find him to be their Sanctifier. His Sabbaths are under his bleſſing the ſpecial means of that little Holineſs that is in the world. Not only is the form of Godlineſs kept up in the world by the keeping the Sabbath day, but alſo that power of Godlineſs which is, or ever has been, in the Church of God, is owing hereunto. In this way Sinners muſt ſeek after Sanctification, and in this way they experience and find it. As it is written in the Pſalm or Song for the Sabbath-day; Pſ. 92.13.
They that be planted in the houſe of the Lord, ſhall flouriſh in the Courts of our God; to ſhew that▪ the Lord is upright;— A God faithful to his Covenant and true to his Inſtitutions, to own and bleſs them.
AND thus I have offer'd ſome hints toward the explaining my Text, How the Sabbaths of God are a ſign between Him and his people, that he is the Lord that doth ſanctify them.

NOW the Argument from all is, That verily his Sabbaths we muſt keep. And you may eaſily perceive a variety of Argument, cogent and very weighty, in what has been ſaid.— The Lord's day is unto us the primary, perpetual and univerſal Memorial of the Covenant of Grace, which God has made with fallen man; and ſhall we not thankfully and religiouſly celebrate the Memorial of this Grace of God unto us?— It is the badge and livery of our being the Covenant People of God; our public and ſolemn Confeſſion of the Lord Jehovah, Father Son and Holy Ghoſt, our glorious Creator, Redeemer and Sanctifier.— It is the great and ſolemn Profeſſion of our Faith in, our devotion unto, and our covenanting with, the moſt High God, Poſſeſſor of heaven and earth.— It is the inſtituted Means to us of Grace here and Glory for ever; of preſent Communion with God and of ſeeing him hereafter; of his having any ſervice and glory from us in this world, and of our finding bleſſedneſs in him in that which is to come.
